creditline: Gift of James A. Bergquist, Boston, in honor of Rachel McGarry
description: tall church building at left; two monks with a child at center bottom; children and women on steps at left; waterway with figure in a rowboat at left; ochre, black, and white
inscription:
In stone, at bottom: PFARR-KIRCHE ZU BOPPART AM RHEIN.
Lower right, in pencil: selten!
medium: Crayon-manner lithograph printed in black ink over one ochre tint stone.
portfolio: From Sammlung denkwürdiger Gebäude des Mittelalters in Deautschland
signed: In the stone, lower left: DQuaglio.pinx.del.1822.
text: The Romantic movement led to renewed appreciation for buildings surviving from the Middle Ages and for the beauty of mans coexistence with nature. Both of these strands are found in Domenico Quaglio's poetic study of Boppart, a small town along the Rhine River, now known as Boppard and now designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The Gothic building at the right is a 13th-century parrish church. Quaglio presents us with an idyllic world in which gnarled oak tree, a pleasant stream and ancient buildings provide a safe and peaceful environment for the townspeople.
title: Parish Church of Boppard, on the Rhine
